users.about_me:
PUBLICATIONS: 
I am the Author of ***Railway Knitting Workbook*** (2015) available from Friesen Press. This covers the basics of Tunisian crochet but also includes several unusual techniques which I have not seen written up before. As of March 2024 it is only available as an e-book.
[link text][1]
***Railway Knitting*** (2012) is a free PDF of the basic stitches and can be downloaded here: [link text][2]
***Tunisian half-double crochet stitches*** (2018) directions and patterns [link text][3]

I am also known as The Railway Knitter as part of VIA Rail's Artists on Board program
If you Google:"Railway Knitting" there are several articles on line about this activity

**2020 train trips** 
Completed train #2, January 20/ train #1 February 2/



**2019 crochet cruise completed** Panama October 25-November 9; http://crochet-cruises.com/panama-cruise.html
2018 crochet cruise completed Celebrity Reflection February 19-March 2
http://crochet-cruises.com/southern-caribbean.html
2016 crochet cruise completed Celebrity Infinity, Alaska, August 28 to September 4
2015 crochet cruises: completed: Carnival Glory, eastern Caribbean, February 7-14 and western Caribbean, February 14-21.
2019 train trips: 3
2018 train trips: 7
2017 train trips: 5
2016 train trips: 5
2015 Train Trips: 3
2014 VIA Rail train trips: 6

The Crochet Crowd: [link text][4]

  [3]: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1-B8GCMgBLaIPfQ9Nyh-CygzlKZfu9Usk/view?usp=sharing
  [4]: http://thecrochetcrowd.com/

264164.name: Stefan's Wheelchair Sweater
264164.gauge_description: 13 stitches and 12.5 rows = 4 inches in TSS
264164.notes_html:
This sweater is specially designed for persons sitting in wheelchair and persons that have difficulties in dressing themselves. There are bi-directional zippers on both sleeves, so that they can be opened both at the top and at the bottom. The front is a little shorter than on other sweaters (so that it will look better when seated) and a little longer in the back (to cover the lower back when seated).

The sweater is crocheted top-down, i.e. you start at the collar and work downwards. No parts are crocheted in the round.

This is also a fairly quick and easy pattern (compared with other sweaters of my design).
264164.notes:

The sweater is crocheted top-down, i.e. you start at the collar and work downwards. No parts are crocheted in the round.

This is also a fairly quick and easy pattern (compared with other sweaters of my design).

pattern_source.author: Patrick Hassel-Zein
pattern_source.name: Tunisian Crochet for Leisure and Pleasure

pattern_author.name: Patrick Hassel-Zein
pattern_author.notes:
*The patterns that I publish here on Ravelry are generally in English, but a bit of Swedish and Icelandic may occasionally show up.*

**What I do:** Since 2008 I’m mainly design and teach Tunisian crochet, and have invented some own techniques to work Tunisian crochet in the round, in colours, in lace patterns, with cables, and so on. I like designing clothes with unusual details or features, and particularly like garments that can be worn in more than one way. It also does happen that I design knitted sweaters. During 2014-2016 I've also been busy with folkloric techniques, such as sewing, tapestry crochet, tablet weaving and leather work.

**Book #1:** In June 2010 I published the book "Tunisian crochet in Icelandic" with 20 patterns (plus variations) for men, women and children. The designs are simple and basic, a bit chunky, and the colours are mostly earth tones. All patterns are available in English in my Ravelry shop.

**Book #2:** In October 2011 I published the book "Tunisian crochet for leisure and pleasure" with 30 new patterns (plus variations). It contains new and improved technique, some new stitches, designs in both thinner and thicker yarn, patters clearly inspired by scifi, fantasy and fairytales, some items for the very smallest children, as well as more vivid colours. Sizes range from 2-14 years and XS-4X. English translations of all patterns and some of the instructions are available in my Ravelry shop.

**Tunisian Crochet by Zein Design 2012:** This is my collection of nine patterns in Tunisian crochet created during 2012. The style is similar to book #2. All patterns are available in English in my Ravelry shop.

**Tunisian Crochet by Zein Design 2013:** This is my collection of eleven patterns in Tunisian crochet created during 2013. My technique is developing further, new stitches are added, and more and more patterns contain short rows (mainly designs with plaited strips). All patterns are available in English in my Ravelry shop.

**Tunisian Crochet by Zein Design 2014-2015:** Six patterns for accessories have been published for this collection. There are two hats, two scarves, a shawl, and a pair of fingered mittens. All patterns are available in English in my Ravelry shop.

**Other patterns:** I've published a collection of knitted sweaters, called "[Patrick Zein‘s Knitted Sweaters][1]", and a free collection of folkloric accessoires called "[Tillbehör till Karleby mansdräkt][2]”. I also have a folder with some assorted items, that don't quite fit in the other collections, called "[Patrick Hassel-Zein's Odd Patterns][3]".

**Assistance:** If you need help to interpret my patterns in Tunisian crochet, you can check out my "fan group" [Inspired by Iceland][4].

**Further reading:** Additional information about my crocheted and knitted designs can be found at [http://www.zein.se/design/][5] and also [on Facebook][6].


  [1]: http://www.ravelry.com/patterns/sources/patrick-zeins-knitted-sweaters
  [2]: http://www.ravelry.com/patterns/sources/tillbehor-till-karleby-mansdrakt
  [3]: http://www.ravelry.com/patterns/sources/patrick-hassel-zeins-odd-patterns
  [4]: http://www.ravelry.com/groups/inspired-by-iceland
  [5]: http://www.zein.se/design/
  [6]: http://www.facebook.com/ZeinDesign

What I do: Since 2008 I’m mainly design and teach Tunisian crochet, and have invented some own techniques to work Tunisian crochet in the round, in colours, in lace patterns, with cables, and so on. I like designing clothes with unusual details or features, and particularly like garments that can be worn in more than one way. It also does happen that I design knitted sweaters. During 2014-2016 I’ve also been busy with folkloric techniques, such as sewing, tapestry crochet, tablet weaving and leather work.

Book #1: In June 2010 I published the book “Tunisian crochet in Icelandic” with 20 patterns (plus variations) for men, women and children. The designs are simple and basic, a bit chunky, and the colours are mostly earth tones. All patterns are available in English in my Ravelry shop.

Book #2: In October 2011 I published the book “Tunisian crochet for leisure and pleasure” with 30 new patterns (plus variations). It contains new and improved technique, some new stitches, designs in both thinner and thicker yarn, patters clearly inspired by scifi, fantasy and fairytales, some items for the very smallest children, as well as more vivid colours. Sizes range from 2-14 years and XS-4X. English translations of all patterns and some of the instructions are available in my Ravelry shop.

Tunisian Crochet by Zein Design 2012: This is my collection of nine patterns in Tunisian crochet created during 2012. The style is similar to book #2. All patterns are available in English in my Ravelry shop.

Tunisian Crochet by Zein Design 2013: This is my collection of eleven patterns in Tunisian crochet created during 2013. My technique is developing further, new stitches are added, and more and more patterns contain short rows (mainly designs with plaited strips). All patterns are available in English in my Ravelry shop.

Tunisian Crochet by Zein Design 2014-2015: Six patterns for accessories have been published for this collection. There are two hats, two scarves, a shawl, and a pair of fingered mittens. All patterns are available in English in my Ravelry shop.

Other patterns: I’ve published a collection of knitted sweaters, called “Patrick Zein‘s Knitted Sweaters”, and a free collection of folkloric accessoires called “Tillbehör till Karleby mansdräkt”. I also have a folder with some assorted items, that don’t quite fit in the other collections, called “Patrick Hassel-Zein’s Odd Patterns”.

users.fave_colors: Moss green, crystal blue, chestnut brown...
users.fave_curse: I prefer not to swear. If I do swear, I choose a language that nobody will understand - like Mandarin or Finnish.
users.about_me:
**About me:** I was born and raised in Sweden, but lived in Iceland 2000-2016. I work as a computer consultant, but have many spare time interests; Templar Knight, scout leader, fan of Star Trek and, of course, like to innovate in knitting, crochet and other textile crafts. I speak Swedish, English, German, Italian, Icelandic and Mandarin Chinese.

**What I do:** Since 2008 I’m mainly design and teach Tunisian crochet, and have invented some own techniques to work Tunisian crochet in the round, in colours, in lace patterns, with cables, and so on. I like designing clothes with unusual details or features, and particularly like garments that can be worn in more than one way. It also does happen that I design knitted sweaters and work with folkloric textile techniques, such as tapestry crochet and tablet weaving.

**Published books:** I've published two books on Tunisian crochet in June 2010 and October 2011. These books were written in Icelandic and Swedish, but English translations of all patterns and most techniques are available in the Ravelry shop.

**Publishing on Ravelry:** A growing number of freestanding new patterns and bundles or patterns added from time to time. My technique is developing and taking new turns. All these patterns are published in English in the Ravelry shop.

**My main goals with my patterns are:**
1) At least 50% of the patterns should be made (primarily) for men.
2) All patterns should be available in a wide range of sizes (generally XS-4X).
3) I strive to invent new/unusual types of garments.
4) Garments that can be varied or worn in different ways make me extra happy.

**The group "[Inspired by Iceland][1]"** here on Ravelry was created "for those of you who are inspired by my designs and are eager to try them."

**Further reading** can be found on my page about [my design in Tunisian crochet and knitting][2] as well as [on Facebook][3].

**[Folk costumes][4]:** Since I've made all pieces of my own folk costumes by hand, my interest in the subject has grown. In 2015 I created a Ravelry group in order to see how many other crafters with folkloric interests I can find. I've posted folcloric patterns in my publications "[Patrick Hassel-Zein's Odd Patterns][5]" and "[Tillbehör till Karleby mansdräkt][6]". This section contains mostly traditional designs from [Ostrobothnia][7] in Finland.


  [1]: http://www.ravelry.com/groups/inspired-by-iceland
  [2]: http://www.zein.se/design
  [3]: http://www.facebook.com/ZeinDesign
  [4]: http://www.ravelry.com/groups/folk-costumes
  [5]: http://www.ravelry.com/patterns/sources/patrick-hassel-zeins-odd-patterns
  [6]: http://www.ravelry.com/patterns/sources/tillbehor-till-karleby-mansdrakt
  [7]: http://www.ravelry.com/patterns/search#sort=best&query=ostrobothnia

I like designing clothes with unusual details or features, and particularly like garments that can be worn in more than one way. It also does happen that I design knitted sweaters and work with folkloric textile techniques, such as tapestry crochet and tablet weaving.

Published books: I’ve published two books on Tunisian crochet in June 2010 and October 2011. These books were written in Icelandic and Swedish, but English translations of all patterns and most techniques are available in the Ravelry shop.

Publishing on Ravelry: A growing number of freestanding new patterns and bundles or patterns added from time to time. My technique is developing and taking new turns. All these patterns are published in English in the Ravelry shop.

My main goals with my patterns are:

The group “Inspired by Iceland” here on Ravelry was created “for those of you who are inspired by my designs and are eager to try them.”

Further reading can be found on my page about my design in Tunisian crochet and knitting as well as on Facebook.

Folk costumes: Since I’ve made all pieces of my own folk costumes by hand, my interest in the subject has grown. In 2015 I created a Ravelry group in order to see how many other crafters with folkloric interests I can find. 277881.name: Knitted Ice Pack Cozy
277881.gauge_description: 22 stitches and 29 rows = 4 inches in Stockinette
277881.notes_html: Here is a pattern for a soft washable ice pack cozy. I used a silk bamboo to give it the softness and strength it needed for the task at hand. The cozy has a flap versus a button. I can’t see wanting a button in my face or pressing against my knee or ankle if I am already in pain! This pattern works perfectly with a standard 3M Nexcare Reusable Ice Pack that can be purchased at any popular pharmacy or grocery store.
277881.notes: Here is a pattern for a soft washable ice pack cozy. I used a silk bamboo to give it the softness and strength it needed for the task at hand. The cozy has a flap versus a button. I can't see wanting a button in my face or pressing against my knee or ankle if I am already in pain! This pattern works perfectly with a standard 3M Nexcare Reusable Ice Pack that can be purchased at any popular pharmacy or grocery store.

users.about_me: I love creating new projects all the time, and I rarely make the same thing twice. I adore cables and textures. I have champagne tastes but a beer can budget. Like many knitters I can find the most expensive yarn in the store. Unfortunately I then fall in love with it and carrying it around with me through the store like a puppy in a pet store! The stares I get are very interesting. :) Giving my projects away as gifts is the best part of the project. I am excited to begin my journey of creating my own designs! Often I look through several magazines and books not finding that special design I am looking for. I soon will start posting the crazy whimsical designs I have in my head. Stay tuned! My favorite yarns to knit with are... **The Yarns of Rhichard Devrieze** 220 Wool by Cascade Yarns Merino Worsted by Malabrigo Yarn Simply Soft by Caron 220 Superwash by Cascade Yarns Merino Worsted by Malabrigo Yarn Sock by Malabrigo Yarn Socks that Rock Lightweight by Blue Moon Fiber Arts Stroll Solids by Knit Picks Swish Worsted by Knit Picks "Little" Skinny Bugga by Cephalopod Yarns Bugga by Cephalopod Yarns

The stares I get are very interesting. :)

Giving my projects away as gifts is the best part of the project. I am excited to begin my journey of creating my own designs! 281681.name: Raynaud's Relief Mittens
281681.notes_html: These mittens feature a pocket for inserting commercial air activated handwarmers and prevent the handwarmer ingredients from darkening fingernails. A must have winter accessory for Raynaud sufferers.
281681.notes: These mittens feature a pocket for inserting commercial air activated handwarmers and prevent the handwarmer ingredients from darkening fingernails.  A must have winter accessory for Raynaud sufferers.

users.about_me:
I'm addicted to yarn, books, and chocolate, and when I'm not working, reading, or knitting, I am the human slave of four adorable demon kitties, Hermes St. James, Bastet Ramses, Lady Morrigan of the Void, and Sir Gwydion Yellsalot. Yes, they all know their full names and they all know it means they're in trouble. 

I am also a novelist. I write YA and urban fantasy under the name [Sophia Beaumont][1], and adult historical fiction and horror under the name [Sine Peril.][2]  Most of my books involve knitting or fiber arts in some way.

My paypal is knotmagickknitter@gmail.com


  [1]: https://www.amazon.com/author/sophiabeaumont
  [2]: https://www.amazon.com/author/sineperil

417377.name: Ice Pack Socks
417377.notes_html:
This is a general method pattern for adding a pocket to the sole of a sock. The pocket is used to hold an ice pack against the sole of the foot, which can help people who suffer from foot pain at night.

The knitter first needs to choose a simple sock pattern to make, of the design, yarn weight, and length that they like. Then follow my instructions on how to make the pocket. My particular example was knit in 8 ply, for a quick project.

Gauge isn’t important, nor is size, as this is a ‘knit until it fits the right shape’ sort of pattern.

The pocket will only add a small amount of yardage to the sock pattern you choose.

NB: these socks are for bed wear only, not for walking in — you may burst the ice pack if you walk on it!

418892.name: Pliable Ice Pack
418892.gauge_description: 4.5 stitches and 7 rows = 1 inch in stockinette
418892.notes_html:
Tired of rice/wheat bags not staying cold for very long - this Pliable Ice Pack lives up to its name …. it stays pliable, even though it has been in the freezer & it stays cold for a long time.

A very quick knit project that also uses up stash yarn for you. ˚Ü˚
418892.notes:

A very quick knit project that also uses up stash yarn for you.   ˚Ü˚

473289.name: Hooded Autism Scarf
473289.gauge_description: 4.5 stitches and 6 rows = 4 inches in Garter
473289.notes_html:
This is a hooded scarf for children, teens, and adults with a sensory disorder, but if you think they’re cute, that’s cool too.

The pattern requires stitch markers, ~500 yards of worsted weight yarn(my favorites are Caron Simply Soft, Lion Brand Heartland, and Red Heart Soft), and size 8-10 knitting needles. You will need to know how to knit, purl, k2tog (and p2tog), yo, sew (hand sew - just for the pockets), and kitchener stitch (I like knitted kitchener stitch).

Gauge isn’t super important, anywhere from 4-5 sts an inch should work just fine.

As a note, you can use the border on the hood to do cables!
(You can use more than one color if you’d like to have stripes)

--They have pockets on the ends of the scarf for stim toys or phones/ipods, or anything else.

--The hood has little button type holes to run a headphone cord through so you can listen to calming music without dangling cords getting in your way.

--There is a little ‘pocket’ in the each of the pockets. Knit squares to put inside, and they can be scented to give a calming effect. Hold the end of the scarf near your nose and you’ll be able to smell whatever scent you have. If you do not want to have the scents, just don’t make the mini pockets or the squares.
My favorite thing is to store the ‘pillows’ in a box of tea bags and take them out when I need to refresh, because they smell amazing for a while afterwards. You can also make your own sachets to put in the small pockets, if that’s what you’d prefer.

If you need any help with the pattern, please contact me and I will help you as soon as possible.
473289.notes:
This is a hooded scarf for children, teens, and adults with a sensory disorder, but if you think they're cute, that's cool too.

The pattern requires stitch markers, ~500 yards of worsted weight yarn(my favorites are Caron Simply Soft, Lion Brand Heartland, and Red Heart Soft), and size 8-10 knitting needles. You will need to know how to knit, purl, k2tog (and p2tog), yo, sew (hand sew - just for the pockets), and kitchener stitch (I like knitted kitchener stitch). 

Gauge isn't super important, anywhere from 4-5 sts an inch should work just fine.

As a note, you can use the border on the hood to do cables!
(You can use more than one color if you'd like to have stripes)

--They have pockets on the ends of the scarf for stim toys or phones/ipods, or anything else.

--The hood has little button type holes to run a headphone cord through so you can listen to calming music without dangling cords getting in your way.

--There is a little 'pocket' in the each of the pockets. Knit squares to put inside, and they can be scented to give a calming effect. Hold the end of the scarf near your nose and you'll be able to smell whatever scent you have. If you do not want to have the scents, just don't make the mini pockets or the squares.
My favorite thing is to store the 'pillows' in a box of tea bags and take them out when I need to refresh, because they smell amazing for a while afterwards. You can also make your own sachets to put in the small pockets, if that's what you'd prefer.


If you need any help with the pattern, please contact me and I will help you as soon as possible.

525680.name: Super Easy Slipper Socks
525680.gauge_description: 15 stitches and 16 rows = 4 inches in BLO Single Crochet
525680.notes_html:
These might be the easiest socks you’ll ever crochet! Worked sideways in rows for extra stretch and comfort, these simple socks will keep your toes toasty warm.

CLICK HERE to see the FREE Written Pattern on my blog.

OR purchase the Large Print, Ad-Free, Printable PDF version of the pattern with the video tutorial by clicking the “Buy Now” button above.

Instructions for extra wide feet are included. These are great for swollen feet or ankles, and make a great gift if you don’t know the recipient’s exact shoe size.

3 Sizes Included in this pattern:

Size Small - Fits Ladies Shoe Sizes 4-5 (will stretch up to a 7)
Size Medium - Fits Ladies Shoe Sizes 6-8
Size Large - Fits Ladies Shoe Sizes 9-10

The skill level is Advanced Beginner.

Pattern includes:
Gauge measurements in inches and centimeters
7 pages of instructions
16 instructional photographs
Printer-friendly version without photos

Supplies:
US Size I (5.5 mm) crochet hook
For Extra Wide Feet, you will also need US Size J (6.0 mm) crochet hook
About 135 (170, 200) yds of #4 worsted weight yarn
Yarn needle or blunt tapestry needle
Scissors
Ruler (for measuring gauge)

This pattern is intended for your personal use only. You may not share it, copy it, sell it, give it away, or mass-produce the finished product. However, you may sell the finished socks on a small scale, as long as you convey in your item description that you used a Yay For Yarn / Mini Giggle Gear pattern.

Yay For Yarn / Mini Giggle Gear Copyright© 2014- Current. All patterns and photos are owned by Yay For Yarn / Mini Giggle Gear.
525680.notes:
These might be the easiest socks you’ll ever crochet! Worked sideways in rows for extra stretch and comfort, these simple socks will keep your toes toasty warm.

**[CLICK HERE to see the FREE Written Pattern on my blog.][1]**

**OR purchase the Large Print, Ad-Free, Printable PDF version of the pattern with the video tutorial by clicking the “Buy Now” button above.**

Instructions for extra wide feet are included. These are great for swollen feet or ankles, and make a great gift if you don’t know the recipient's exact shoe size.

**3 Sizes Included in this pattern:**

*Size Small - Fits Ladies Shoe Sizes 4-5 (will stretch up to a 7)
*Size Medium - Fits Ladies Shoe Sizes 6-8
*Size Large - Fits Ladies Shoe Sizes 9-10

The skill level is Advanced Beginner.

**Pattern includes:**
Gauge measurements in inches and centimeters
7 pages of instructions
16 instructional photographs
Printer-friendly version without photos

**Supplies:**
US Size I (5.5 mm) crochet hook
For Extra Wide Feet, you will also need US Size J (6.0 mm) crochet hook
About 135 (170, 200) yds of #4 worsted weight yarn
Yarn needle or blunt tapestry needle
Scissors
Ruler (for measuring gauge)

**This pattern is intended for your personal use only. You may not share it, copy it, sell it, give it away, or mass-produce the finished product. However, you may sell the finished socks on a small scale, as long as you convey in your item description that you used a Yay For Yarn / Mini Giggle Gear pattern.**

**Yay For Yarn / Mini Giggle Gear Copyright© 2014- Current. All patterns and photos are owned by Yay For Yarn / Mini Giggle Gear.** 


  [1]: https://yayforyarn.com/super-easy-slipper-socks-free-crochet-pattern/

539721.name: The Sleevescarf
539721.sizes_available: 5 sizes (by upper arm circumference). Adult XS- 9in/22.5cm, S- 10in/25.5cm (shown), M- 12in/30.5cm, L- 14in/35.5cm, XL- 15in/38cm.
539721.notes_html:
I made my first sleevescarf years ago, and never could have guessed how much I would still love it today. It’s my go-to scarf; partly because it has so many coordinated colors that despite being kind of loud it matches almost everything, and partly because I can shove my hands into the ends and not also have to remember mittens.

Yarn: Select a worsted or aran weight yarn you use frequently, get at least one skein to use for the borders and as the “main” stripe color, then add some half-skeins and leftovers in other colors. You can line them all up and weed out any colors that really look out of place with the others.

Shown in: Lamb’s Pride Worsted (190 yds/174 m, 113 g/3.99 oz) I used 6 colors, you can use more or less. MC: Oregano. CCs are: Aubergine, Turquoise Depths, Blue Boy, an unidentified Red, and a discontinued sky blue. Total yardage will depend on length, I used about 350yds/320m for the size S sleevescarf shown above. For the 2 largest sizes, 2 skeins of the MC might be needed, it will depend on how long and how frequently you make MC stripes.

Gauge: 4st/in. (16 sts/4in, 16 sts/10cm).
Needles: DPNs US size 6/4mm (or size needed to obtain gauge), and a large circular needle of the same size.
Sizes: 5 sizes (by upper arm circumference). Adult XS- 9in/22.5cm, S- 10in/25.5cm (shown), M- 12in/30.5cm, L- 14in/35.5cm, XL- 15in/38cm. Select a size with about .5in/1.27cm to 1in/2.5in negative ease. See “Customize” section on P 2. for: standard arm/cross back measurements, and how to to make a custom size or alter gauge.
Skills: knit, purl, knit and purl through back loop, knit in the round, knit flat, cast on, cast off, place sts on holder or scrap yarn. Includes brief tutorial for spit-splicing. Provisional cast on (optional).
Accessibility Notes: 12 point serif font with bolded and underlined headings, no columns (except for abbreviation key). Due to ability to rest hands inside of scarf for additional layer of warmth (especially when caught off guard by the weather), it may be particularly useful to those with circulatory problems (such as Raynauds).

Note: Pattern file updated 10/30/17 with: expanded size selection, schematic, length suggestions and improved layout. Thanks!

553669.name: Socks for wide feet
553669.notes_html:
Many people suffer from swollen ankles and feet due to medical conditions and after surgery. Commercially available socks often have small cuffs that become tight when the ankles swell and can cut into the skin. Equally, commercially available socks are usually rather narrow in the foot, and don’t allow for a wider, flatter foot or for high insteps. This pattern aims to address these common issues, while at the same time, giving you a pretty pair of socks with some interesting detail. There are also instructions for a plain pair of socks, suitable for a man or a woman.

This pattern is suitable for intermediate experienced knitters, due to the shaping involved.

The pattern requires approximately 300 m of 4 ply / fingering yarn to complete one pair of socks, plus double point needles. To fit UK women shoe size: 7-8 (and up to 8E wide).

users.about_me:
Kite flying mad hare lady, spending time in Texas each year with Hubby who is in prison. Loves rock, blues & classical music. Attempting to return to garden designing now that I have passed my driving test! 

Spending a lot of time at the moment on family history research (Payne, Gough, Sansum and Lay).

I spin, generally from fleeces rather than roving or tops, on my Ashford wheel. If you are interested in purchasing some of my yarn, check out my Etsy or Folksy shops below or send me a message here. 

Also co-founder of the [Texas Prison Support][1] forum - an information resource for anyone who knows someone incarcerated in TDCJ.

Now selling on [Folksy][2] too!


  [1]: http://texasprisonsupport.createaforum.com/
  [2]: https://folksy.com/shops/silvapagan

559487.name: Easy-Peasy Knittn' Mittens
559487.gauge_description: 4.25 stitches and 6.5 rows = 1 inch in Stockinette
559487.notes_html:
Easy-Peasy Knittn’ Mittens
H.L. Fuller
These simple fingerless mitts have a split, ribbed cuff, and may, optionally, be modestly embellished with a pinstripe of contrasting yarn. Here is a great fate for scraps of leftover aran-weight or worsted yarn. They’ll be a boon to anyone who types in a cold office, or works with her hands and has developed a touch of arthritis or tendonitis in her knuckles.
You’ll need about 65 yards (50 grams; 1.8 oz) of worsted or aran weight in your main colorway, and (optionally) a couple two three yards of a contrasting colorway to make a pinstripe.
The main body of the mitt is worked on size 7 needles (straight and dpn), and the thumb is worked on size 3 dpn.
You also need a stitch holder and two stitch markers.
You can custom tailor the circumference easily; measure around the hand at the widest point (knuckles) and multiply that value in inches by 4. That’s the number of stitches to cast on. The instructions are given for a hand that measures 8 inches in circumference at the knuckles – women’s medium.

Easy-Peasy Knittn' Mittens
H.L. Fuller

You also need a stitch holder and two stitch markers.
You can custom tailor the circumference easily; measure around the hand at the widest point (knuckles) and multiply that value in inches by 4. That's the number of stitches to cast on. The instructions are given for a hand that measures 8 inches in circumference at the knuckles – women's medium.

564578.gauge_pattern: stocking stitch in the round on smaller needles
564578.name: Inside-Out Hypnosis
564578.gauge_description: 36 stitches and 52 rows = 4 inches in stocking stitch in the round on smaller needles
564578.notes_html:
With reference to the well-known “pea problem” that a princess once happened to have, the Princess Sole consists in the smoothest, softest of all soles, with the “right side” of the stocking stitch in contact with the skin, and the naughty purl bumps on the outside of the sock.

Working a Princess Sole is most of the time synonymous with Purling though. Thus creating another well-known problem in the knitting community: the widely spread avoidance for major purling events! But… this was before the creation of the Inside-Out Hypnosis socks: the comfort of the Princess Sole, and hardly any purling…

« Tu me fais tourner la tête
Mon manège à moi, c’est toi! » — Edith Piaf

Message aux francophones: Si l’anglais n’est pas votre premiere langue, mais que vous souhaitez vous lancer et tricoter un de mes designs, n’hesitez pas ! Je peux vous aider a traduire des passages qui vous poseraient probleme, et, si il y a une demande suffisante, me lancer dans la traduction complete de mes modeles.

Sizing
To fit foot circumference (measured around ball of foot):
Small ― 20 cm (8 in),
Medium ― 23 cm (9 in),
Large ― 25.5 cm(10 in)]

Yarn requirement
The Knitting Goddess British wool and nylon 4ply (1 x 100g, 400 m / 437 yds) shown in Red Orchid
or The Knitting Goddess merino nylon 4ply (1 x 100g, 424 m / 465 yds) shown in Semi-solid Brick

Needles and Notions

  • 2.25 mm (US 1) needles (circ. or DPNs) - Or size required to achieve gauge.
  • 2.75 mm (US 3) needles for tubular cast-on
  • Cable needle
  • Darning needle
  • Stitch markers
  • Waste yarn and crochet hook

Gauge
36 sts and 52 rows / 10cm (4 in) measured over stockinette in the round with smaller needles.

7-Page Pattern includes:
Detailed charts for all patterned sections.
Complete written instructions (including written directions for Charts)
Photo-Tutorial of Shadow Wrap technique.

More detailed tutorial on the Shadow Wrap method, as well as a photo-tutorial featuring the elongated stitch can be found on the designer’s blog.

*Working a Princess Sole is most of the time synonymous with Purling though. Thus creating another well-known problem in the knitting community: the widely spread avoidance for major purling events! But... this was before the creation of the Inside-Out Hypnosis socks: the comfort of the Princess Sole, and hardly any purling...*

*« Tu me fais tourner la tête

---

or The Knitting Goddess merino nylon 4ply (1 x 100g, 424 m / 465 yds) shown in Semi-solid Brick

**Needles and Notions**
* 2.25 mm (US 1) needles (circ. or DPNs) - Or size required to achieve gauge.
* 2.75 mm (US 3) needles for tubular cast-on
* Cable needle
* Darning needle
* Stitch markers
* Waste yarn and crochet hook

**Gauge**
36 sts and 52 rows / 10cm (4 in) measured over stockinette in the round with smaller needles.

**7-Page Pattern includes:**
Detailed charts for all patterned sections. 
Complete written instructions (including written directions for  Charts)
Photo-Tutorial of Shadow Wrap technique.

More detailed tutorial on the Shadow Wrap method, as well as a photo-tutorial featuring the elongated stitch can be found on [the designer's blog][2].

users.fave_colors: Any natural colour, all colours of autumn, and some blues too...
users.about_me:
<del>Recently moved to Al Khobar, Saudi Arabia, from Aberdeen, Scotland. Please bear with me while I adapt to the different lifestyle and... climate!</del>

And... I just moved from Saudi Arabia to the other sand pit next door, the UAE. Bear with me while I try to adjust... it's harder for me than the previous change. 

---

*“If only there were more than 24 hours in a day, I would spend these extra hours knitting and making things. The design process, to me, is more of a journey, where maths and engineering cross the path of traditions and creativity.*

*Most of the things I make, whether knitting or not-knitting (why, yes, there is a world beside knitting!?), are about the challenge: I like to challenge myself, and to challenge my brain. But I also enjoy the sheer satisfaction of a simple and pretty design, which is pleasing to the eye and a joy to wear.”*

---

Join us! For updates on upcoming designs, knit-alongs and general chatter, please join [The Auld Woolly Alliance](/groups/the-auld-woolly-alliance) group!
users.about_me_html:
Recently moved to Al Khobar, Saudi Arabia, from Aberdeen, Scotland. Please bear with me while I adapt to the different lifestyle and… climate!

And… I just moved from Saudi Arabia to the other sand pit next door, the UAE. Bear with me while I try to adjust… it’s harder for me than the previous change.

“If only there were more than 24 hours in a day, I would spend these extra hours knitting and making things. The design process, to me, is more of a journey, where maths and engineering cross the path of traditions and creativity.

Most of the things I make, whether knitting or not-knitting (why, yes, there is a world beside knitting!?), are about the challenge: I like to challenge myself, and to challenge my brain. But I also enjoy the sheer satisfaction of a simple and pretty design, which is pleasing to the eye and a joy to wear.”

Join us! For updates on upcoming designs, knit-alongs and general chatter, please join The Auld Woolly Alliance group!

570625.name: Boo-boo Buddies
570625.notes_html:
These caring critters are ready to apply some cool and soothing help for little bumps and bruises. Filled with dried beans, these all natural, soft, and adorable cotton ice packs provide 10–15 minutes of gentle, cooling relief.

Skill level: Beginner

Finished measurements: 7” tall x 4” wide

Materials

• 1 skein Crème de la Crème by Red Heart, 100% cotton (125 yds/70.9g) in each of colors 331 Fudge Brown (A), 118 Linen (B), 679 Spruce (C), 701 Orchid Pink (D), 870 Cornfl ower Blue (E), 1 White (F), 12 Black (G)
• U.S. size 5 (3.75mm) needles
• Yarn needle
• 2 cups dried beans
• Black felt
• Fabric glue

pattern_author.name: Megan Kreiner
pattern_author.notes:
Started in 2012, the brands of MK Crochet and MK Knits feature the toy design work of artist, animator, and author Megan Kreiner. During lunch breaks and after her kids are tucked into bed at night, Megan picks up her sketch book (or iPad) and yarn and designs toys that encourage imaginative and safe play for children (and adults) of all ages.

Her crochet and knit patterns have been featured in numerous books, crochet and knitting magazines, crochet kits, and a series of Creative Bug video tutorials.

Megan received a Bachelor of Fine Arts degree in computer graphics and animation from the University of Massachusetts, Amherst, and has worked in the feature animation industry in Los Angeles, California as an animator for studios such as Dreamworks Animation and Disney Feature Animation. Her film credits include titles like DreamWorks Animation’s How to Train your Dragon, Kung Fu Panda, and Trolls and Walt Disney Animation's Raya and the last Dragon, Encanto, and Wish.

Megan lives in Los Angeles, California, with her husband Michael, her children, James and Emily, and Olive the cat.
pattern_author.notes_html:
Started in 2012, the brands of MK Crochet and MK Knits feature the toy design work of artist, animator, and author Megan Kreiner. During lunch breaks and after her kids are tucked into bed at night, Megan picks up her sketch book (or iPad) and yarn and designs toys that encourage imaginative and safe play for children (and adults) of all ages.

Her crochet and knit patterns have been featured in numerous books, crochet and knitting magazines, crochet kits, and a series of Creative Bug video tutorials.

Megan received a Bachelor of Fine Arts degree in computer graphics and animation from the University of Massachusetts, Amherst, and has worked in the feature animation industry in Los Angeles, California as an animator for studios such as Dreamworks Animation and Disney Feature Animation. Her film credits include titles like DreamWorks Animation’s How to Train your Dragon, Kung Fu Panda, and Trolls and Walt Disney Animation’s Raya and the last Dragon, Encanto, and Wish.

Megan lives in Los Angeles, California, with her husband Michael, her children, James and Emily, and Olive the cat.

users.about_me:
My name is Megan Kreiner and I am the designer of the MK Crochet / MK Knits pattern collections. 

I learned to knit and crochet at an early age from my grandmother,  my aunt, and started to explore the wild and uncharted waters of toy design and pattern making in 2012 under the brand names "MK Crochet" & "MK Knits".

I have a fine arts degree in computer graphics and animation from the University of Massachusetts, Amherst, and am currently pursuing a career in the feature animation industry in Los Angeles, California as an animator at Walt Disney Animation Studios.

My books are available for purchase online:
**[Crochet a Zoo ~ Fun toys for Baby and You][1]**
**[Bathtime Buddies ~ 20 Crocheted Animals from the Sea][2]**
**[Crochet a Farm ~ 19 Cute-as-Can-Be Barnyard Creations][3]**
**[Creepy Crawly Crochet: 17 Creatures That Go Bump in the Night][4]**
**[Christmas Ornaments to Crochet - 31 Festive and Fun-To -Make Designs for a Handmade Holiday.][5]**
**[Construction Vehicles to Crochet: Chunky Trucks and Marvelous Machines Straight from the Building Site][6]**
**[Dinosaurs to Crochet: Playful Patterns for Crafting Cuddly Prehistoric Wonders][7]**
**[Cuddly Crochet Critters: 26 Animal Patterns][8]**
**[Baby Beast Crochet:Cute Amigurumi Creatures from Myth and Legend][9]**


I also have crochet kits!
**[Disney Classic Crochet][10]**
**[Disney Winnie the Pooh Crochet][11]**
**[Crochet Cats: 10 Adorable Projects for Cat Lovers][12]**
**[Crochet Dogs: 10 Adorable Projects for Dog Lovers][13]**
**[Crochet Horses & Ponies: 10 Adorable Projects for Horse Lovers][14]**



If you would like to take a peek at all of the current MK Crochet patterns please visit my [ravelry designer page][15]!

My name is Megan Kreiner and I am the designer of the MK Crochet / MK Knits pattern collections.

I learned to knit and crochet at an early age from my grandmother, my aunt, and started to explore the wild and uncharted waters of toy design and pattern making in 2012 under the brand names “MK Crochet” & “MK Knits”.

I have a fine arts degree in computer graphics and animation from the University of Massachusetts, Amherst, and am currently pursuing a career in the feature animation industry in Los Angeles, California as an animator at Walt Disney Animation Studios.

My books are available for purchase online:
Crochet a Zoo ~ Fun toys for Baby and You
Bathtime Buddies ~ 20 Crocheted Animals from the Sea
Crochet a Farm ~ 19 Cute-as-Can-Be Barnyard Creations
Creepy Crawly Crochet: 17 Creatures That Go Bump in the Night
Christmas Ornaments to Crochet - 31 Festive and Fun-To -Make Designs for a Handmade Holiday.
Construction Vehicles to Crochet: Chunky Trucks and Marvelous Machines Straight from the Building Site
Dinosaurs to Crochet: Playful Patterns for Crafting Cuddly Prehistoric Wonders
Cuddly Crochet Critters: 26 Animal Patterns
Baby Beast Crochet:Cute Amigurumi Creatures from Myth and Legend

I also have crochet kits!
Disney Classic Crochet
Disney Winnie the Pooh Crochet
Crochet Cats: 10 Adorable Projects for Cat Lovers
Crochet Dogs: 10 Adorable Projects for Dog Lovers
Crochet Horses & Ponies: 10 Adorable Projects for Horse Lovers

If you would like to take a peek at all of the current MK Crochet patterns please visit my ravelry designer page!

578125.name: A-Z Braille Blanket
578125.notes_html:
This pattern is for an A-Z Blanket which is made up of squares which are crocheted in a design which allows them to replicate braille.

The design is achieved by placing popcorn stitches in the correct places for the braille. This has been checked by braille readers as an accurate reflection of braille.

I have also included photo tutorials of how to crochet all of the stitches required and how to attach them together in to a blanket as shown in the picture.

I have also included patterns for braille numbers as well as a template for a Capital letter, a full stop, a question mark and an exclamation mark. This means you have the potential with this pattern to design your own blanket with words in braille so its a very versatile pattern. It would be a great project for a group to do or with someone looking for something a little bit different.

I designed this blanket as my daughter has a visual impairment and I wanted a subtle way to teach her Braille so she had it as a skill without knowing she had learned it. I was selling this pattern with donations going to the Nystagmus Network but wanted to make it free so people could use it but can i please ask if you download it to consider donating £1 to the Nystagmus network. www.justgiving.co.uk/nikki-espiner

623567.name: Super Bulky Wrist Warmers/Gauntlets
623567.notes_html:
I decided to make these for my mother who has arthritis in her hands. She can wear these to keep her wrists and hands warm, and still have the freedom of movement that fingerless gloves have. They work up easily and quickly because of the super bulky yarn, and are really soft and comfy when you use Bernat Blanket yarn.

Materials Needed:
9.0mm or size N hook
54-60 yards of Bernat Blanket yarn (or other Super Bulky yarn of your choosing), about 1/2 of 1 skein
4.25 or size G hook for weaving in ends (much easier than trying to thread a yarn needle)

Sizing:
I sized these to an adult woman’s wrists and hands, you can adjust the number of rows on the cuff (and subsequent stitches on the edge) to make them larger or smaller as needed.
sorry, no gauge information- I crochet a bit tight if that helps.

624010.name: Crochet Sneakers Pattern – PDF Instant Download
624010.notes_html:
Create your own stylish crochet sneakers with this detailed step-by-step pattern! These unique, handmade shoes are perfect for everyday wear or as a fun gift for crochet lovers.

Ohje saatavilla suomeksi ja englanniksi!
Pattern available in Finnish and English!

What’s Included?
✔ Instant PDF download – start crocheting right away!
✔ Step-by-step written instructions in Finnish and English
✔ Detailed step-by-step photos for guidance
✔ Yarn and sole recommendations
✔ Adjustable sizing for a custom fit

Skill Level: Intermediate
Sizes: Customizable

Please note: This is a crochet pattern only, NOT a finished product.

How It Works:
1️⃣ Purchase the pattern
2️⃣ Instantly download the PDF file
3️⃣ Follow the detailed instructions and photos to crochet your own sneakers!

Digital download only – no physical item will be shipped.

✨ Happy crocheting! / Mukavia virkkaushetkiä! ✨

633892.name: Sleepless Malice
633892.gauge_description: 8 stitches and 10.5 rows = 1 inch in Stockinette
633892.notes_html:
Materials needed: 400 yards of a fingering weight yarn in either a tonal or a solid color, US size 1 (2.25 mm) needles, stitch markers (recommended), and a cable needle (recommended).

Textured sock featuring a sloping diamond pattern on the front of the leg, a ring pattern on the back of the leg, and chain mail patterns on the sides; also has a princess sole and toe. Based on J.R.R. Tolkien’s antagonist and titular character of the Lord of the Rings trilogy: Sauron.

Pattern is mostly written with two charts to help with the side panel decreases and the top of the foot panel decreases.

Written to fit a US 7 women’s foot, but can easily be modified to fit other sizes by adding purl stitches between the four different panels on the sock, or by swapping yarn and/or needles.
633892.notes:
Materials needed: 400 yards of a fingering weight yarn in either a tonal or a solid color, US size 1 (2.25 mm) needles, stitch markers (recommended), and a cable needle (recommended).  

Textured sock featuring a sloping diamond pattern on the front of the leg, a ring pattern on the back of the leg, and chain mail patterns on the sides; also has a princess sole and toe. Based on J.R.R. Tolkien's antagonist and titular character of the *Lord of the Rings* trilogy: Sauron. 

Pattern is mostly written with two charts to help with the side panel decreases and the top of the foot panel decreases. 

Written to fit a US 7 women's foot, but can easily be modified to fit other sizes by adding purl stitches between the four different panels on the sock, or by swapping yarn and/or needles.

packs.yarn_name: String Theory Hand Dyed Yarn Caper Sock

pattern_author.name: Jude Melvin
pattern_author.notes:
I'm an aspiring Mortician that's been crafting as a form of mindfulness and stress relief since I was 8 (or 9 not quite sure). When I'm not poking dead things with a stick I enjoy a plethora of nerdy things, like reading all of Tolkien's works, learning everything I can about Norse Mythology, and rocking out to David Bowie or Dead or Alive. I'm also one half of the [KnerdGirl Knits][1] podcast, with my mom [Geknitics][2]. 


  [1]: http://knerdgirlknits.blogspot.com
  [2]: http://www.ravelry.com/people/Geknitics
